title: 110_hr7207
content: The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008, also known as the "Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act," outlines the rights and responsibilities of federal entities in the spectrum relocation process. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 outlines the rights of eligible federal entities to receive payment for relocation costs incurred due to frequency reallocation from Federal to non-Federal use. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 allows eligible federal entities to receive payment for relocation costs when frequencies are reallocated. NTIA must provide public notice of relocation plans within 60 days of notifying the Commission of estimated costs and timelines. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 allows eligible Federal entities to receive payment for relocation costs when frequencies are reallocated. Each entity's transition plan must provide the public with information on current spectrum use, geographic locations of facilities, frequency bands used, and steps for relocation in detail. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 allows eligible Federal entities to receive payment for relocation costs when frequencies are reallocated. Transition plans must include details on spectrum use, locations, interactions with NTIA, staff responsible for relocation efforts, and plans for using relocation funds. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 allows eligible Federal entities to receive payment for relocation costs. Transition plans must include details on spectrum use, locations, interactions with NTIA, staff responsible for relocation efforts, plans for using relocation funds, procuring new equipment, field-testing and deploying new equipment, hiring contract personnel, and risk factors in the relocation process. To be eligible for payment from the Spectrum Relocation Fund, Federal entities must submit transition plans to NTIA at least 60 days before they are made public. Plans are evaluated by a 3-member Technical Panel, which reports to NTIA and the Federal entity within 30 days. The Technical Panel, consisting of members appointed by OMB, NTIA, and FCC, must evaluate transition plans submitted by Federal entities for sufficiency within 30 days. Regulations will govern the panel's operations. The Technical Panel, appointed by OMB, NTIA, and FCC, will evaluate transition plans submitted by Federal entities within 30 days. The panel's operations will be governed by regulations, including public notice and comment, subject to OMB approval. Members of the panel must be appointed within 180 days of the enactment of the Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008. If any required information is classified, the transition plan must explain the exclusion, provide non-classified information, and discuss the risk factor of classified information. The Spectrum Relocation Fund requires Federal entities to include spectrum sharing in their transition plans to be eligible for relocation cost payments. During the transition period, the Federal entity must provide reasonable accommodation for commercial licensees using eligible frequencies, engage in negotiations with licensees within 30 days of a request, and share classified information on a need-to-know basis to assist in the relocation process. To be eligible for relocation cost payment from the Spectrum Relocation Fund, a Federal entity must complete its spectrum relocation within 1 year unless approved for a different timeline by OMB with NTIA's advice. The Spectrum Relocation Fund requires Federal entities to complete spectrum relocation within a specified time period. NTIA must receive a transition plan update halfway through the timeline. Payments from the Fund must be made within 30 days after the auction's first license grant. Dispute resolution process during spectrum relocation involves a 3-member board chaired by a representative of OMB, NTIA, and the Commission. The board must rule on any disputes within 28 days. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 establishes a dispute resolution board to resolve disputes within 28 days. The board is assisted by a Technical Panel and regulations will be adopted by NTIA within 180 days. Appeals can be made to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit within 30 days. Each party is responsible for their own costs and expenses. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 establishes a dispute resolution board with a Technical Panel to resolve disputes within 28 days. Regulations will be adopted by NTIA within 180 days, and appeals can be made to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit within 30 days. Each party is responsible for their own costs and expenses, including attorneys' fees for any litigation related to this subsection.
